verses.teaching: Krishna explains the cosmic cycle: beings depend on food, food comes from rain, rain from sacrifice, sacrifice from action. This shows how all life is interconnected through cycles of giving and receiving.

verses.sanskrit: कर्म ब्रह्मोद्भवं विद्धि ब्रह्माक्षरसमुद्भवम्। तस्मात्सर्वगतं ब्रह्म नित्यं यज्ञे प्रतिष्ठितम्॥
verses.transliteration: karma brahmodbhavaṁ viddhi brahmākṣara-samudbhavam | tasmāt sarva-gataṁ brahma nityaṁ yajñe pratiṣṭhitam ||
verses.translation: Thus action is of Brahma, who is One, the Only, All-pervading; at all times present in sacrifice.
verses.teaching: Action originates from Brahma (the Vedas/Divine), which comes from the imperishable Supreme. Therefore, the all-pervading Brahman is always present in sacrifice, making all righteous action sacred.

verses.sanskrit: एवं प्रवर्तितं चक्रं नानुवर्तयतीह यः। अघायुरिन्द्रियारामो मोघं पार्थ स जीवति॥
verses.transliteration: evaṁ pravartitaṁ cakraṁ nānuvartayatīha yaḥ | aghāyur indriyārāmo moghaṁ pārtha sa jīvati ||
verses.translation: He that abstains to help the rolling wheels of this great world, glutting his idle sense, lives a lost life, shameful and vain. Existing for himself, self-concentrated, serving self alone, no part hath he in aught; nothing achieved, nought wrought or unwrought toucheth him; no hope of help for all the living things of earth depends from him.
verses.teaching: One who does not follow this cycle of sacrifice, who lives only for sensory pleasure, lives uselessly. Such a life is wasted because it contributes nothing to the cosmic order or the welfare of others.

verses.sanskrit: यस्त्वात्मरतिरेव स्यादात्मतृप्तश्च मानवः। आत्मन्येव च सन्तुष्टस्तस्य कार्यं न विद्यते॥
verses.transliteration: yas tv ātma-ratir eva syād ātma-tṛptaś ca mānavaḥ | ātmany eva ca santuṣṭas tasya kāryaṁ na vidyate ||
verses.translation: Therefore, thy task prescribed with spirit unattached gladly perform, since in performance of plain duty man mounts to his highest bliss.
verses.teaching: However, for one who rejoices only in the Self, who is satisfied in the Self, and who is content in the Self alone - for such a person there is no duty. They have transcended obligatory action through self-realization.

verses.sanskrit: नैव तस्य कृतेनार्थो नाकृतेनेह कश्चन। न चास्य सर्वभूतेषु कश्चिदर्थव्यपाश्रयः॥
verses.transliteration: naiva tasya kṛtenārtho nākṛteneha kaścana | na cāsya sarva-bhūteṣu kaścid artha-vyapāśrayaḥ ||
verses.translation: By works alone Janak and ancient saints reached blessedness! Moreover, for the upholding of thy kind, action thou should'st embrace.
verses.teaching: A self-realized person has nothing to gain from action or inaction in this world, and has no need to depend on any being. Yet even such beings may act for the welfare of the world.

verses.sanskrit: तस्मादसक्तः सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर। असक्तो ह्याचरन्कर्म परमाप्नोति पूरुषः॥
verses.transliteration: tasmād asaktaḥ satataṁ kāryaṁ karma samācara | asakto hy ācaran karma param āpnoti pūruṣaḥ ||
verses.translation: What the wise choose the unwise people take; what best men do the multitude will follow.
verses.teaching: Therefore, always perform your duty efficiently and without attachment. By working without attachment one attains the Supreme. This is the path for those still progressing spiritually.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मणैव हि संसिद्धिमास्थिता जनकादयः। लोकसंग्रहमेवापि सम्पश्यन्कर्तुमर्हसि॥
verses.transliteration: karmaṇaiva hi saṁsiddhim āsthitā janakādayaḥ | loka-saṅgraham evāpi sampaśyan kartum arhasi ||
verses.translation: By works alone Janak and ancient saints reached blessedness! Moreover, for the upholding of thy kind, action thou should'st embrace.
verses.teaching: King Janaka and other enlightened rulers attained perfection through action. Even considering the welfare of the world, you should perform your duty. Great souls act as examples for others.

verses.sanskrit: यद्यदाचरति श्रेष्ठस्तत्तदेवेतरो जनः। स यत्प्रमाणं कुरुते लोकस्तदनुवर्तते॥
verses.transliteration: yad yad ācarati śreṣṭhas tat tad evetaro janaḥ | sa yat pramāṇaṁ kurute lokas tad anuvartate ||
verses.translation: What the wise choose the unwise people take; what best men do the multitude will follow.
verses.teaching: Whatever action a great person performs, common people follow. Whatever standards they set by exemplary acts, the world pursues. Leaders have a responsibility to set the right example.

verses.sanskrit: न मे पार्थास्ति कर्तव्यं त्रिषु लोकेषु किञ्चन। नानवाप्तमवाप्तव्यं वर्त एव च कर्मणि॥
verses.transliteration: na me pārthāsti kartavyaṁ triṣu lokeṣu kiñcana | nānavāptam avāptavyaṁ varta eva ca karmaṇi ||
verses.translation: Look on me, thou Son of Pritha! in the three wide worlds I am not bound to any toil, no height awaits to scale, no gift remains to gain, yet I act here!
verses.teaching: Krishna personally has nothing to gain in all three worlds, yet He continues to act. This demonstrates that enlightened action is not motivated by personal need but by universal welfare.

verses.sanskrit: यदि ह्यहं न वर्तेयं जातु कर्मण्यतन्द्रितः। मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः॥
verses.transliteration: yadi hy ahaṁ na varteyaṁ jātu karmaṇy atandritaḥ | mama vartmānuvartante manuṣyāḥ pārtha sarvaśaḥ ||
verses.translation: And, if I acted not—earnest and watchful—those that look to me for guidance, sinking back to sloth again because I slumbered, would decline from good, and I should break earth's order and commit her offspring unto ruin, Bharata!
verses.teaching: If Krishna did not engage in action, people would follow His example and neglect their duties, leading to societal chaos. This shows the responsibility of those who serve as role models.

verses.sanskrit: उत्सीदेयुरिमे लोका न कुर्यां कर्म चेदहम्। सङ्करस्य च कर्ता स्यामुपहन्यामिमाः प्रजाः॥
verses.transliteration: utsīdeyur ime lokā na kuryāṁ karma ced aham | saṅkarasya ca kartā syām upahanyām imāḥ prajāḥ ||
verses.translation: Even as the unknowing toil, wedded to sense, so let the enlightened toil, sense-freed, but set to bring the world deliverance, and its bliss; not sowing in those simple, busy hearts seed of despair.
verses.teaching: If Krishna ceased to work, the worlds would perish. He would be the cause of confusion and would destroy all these people. Even the enlightened must act to maintain cosmic and social order.

verses.sanskrit: सक्ताः कर्मण्यविद्वांसो यथा कुर्वन्ति भारत। कुर्याद्विद्वांस्तथासक्तश्चिकीर्षुर्लोकसंग्रहम्॥
verses.transliteration: saktāḥ karmaṇy avidvāṁso yathā kurvanti bhārata | kuryād vidvāṁs tathāsaktaś cikīrṣur loka-saṅgraham ||
verses.translation: Yea! let each play his part in all he finds to do, with unyoked soul. All things are everywhere by Nature wrought in interaction of the qualities.
verses.teaching: As the ignorant act with attachment to their work, the wise should act without attachment, desiring to lead people on the right path. The wise work for the welfare of the world.

verses.sanskrit: न बुद्धिभेदं जनयेदज्ञानां कर्मसङ्गिनाम्। जोषयेत्सर्वकर्माणि विद्वान्युक्तः समाचरन्॥
verses.transliteration: na buddhi-bhedaṁ janayed ajñānāṁ karma-saṅginām | joṣayet sarva-karmāṇi vidvān yuktaḥ samācaran ||
verses.translation: The fool, cheated by self, thinks, 'This I did' and 'That I wrought;' but—ah, thou strong-armed Prince!—a better-lessoned mind, knowing the play of visible things within the world of sense, and how the qualities must qualify, standeth aloof even from his acts.
verses.teaching: The wise should not unsettle the minds of the ignorant who are attached to action. Instead, they should engage them in all activities while themselves acting with devotion and proper understanding.

verses.sanskrit: प्रकृतेः क्रियमाणानि गुणैः कर्माणि सर्वशः। अहङ्कारविमूढात्मा कर्ताहमिति मन्यते॥
verses.transliteration: prakṛteḥ kriyamāṇāni guṇaiḥ karmāṇi sarvaśaḥ | ahaṅkāra-vimūḍhātmā kartāham iti manyate ||
verses.translation: All things are everywhere by Nature wrought in interaction of the qualities. The fool, cheated by self, thinks, 'This I did' and 'That I wrought.'
verses.teaching: All actions are performed by the modes of material nature, but one deluded by false ego thinks 'I am the doer.' Understanding that nature acts while the Self observes brings freedom.

verses.sanskrit: तत्त्ववित्तु महाबाहो गुणकर्मविभागयोः। गुणा गुणेषु वर्तन्त इति मत्वा न सज्जते॥
verses.transliteration: tattva-vit tu mahā-bāho guṇa-karma-vibhāgayoḥ | guṇā guṇeṣu vartanta iti matvā na sajjate ||
verses.translation: But, ah, thou strong-armed Prince!—a better-lessoned mind, knowing the play of visible things within the world of sense, and how the qualities must qualify, standeth aloof even from his acts.
verses.teaching: One who knows the truth about the divisions of the modes and actions understands that it is the modes acting upon modes. Such a person does not become attached, seeing the Self as separate from action.

verses.sanskrit: प्रकृतेर्गुणसम्मूढाः सज्जन्ते गुणकर्मसु। तानकृत्स्नविदो मन्दान्कृत्स्नविन्न विचालयेत्॥
verses.transliteration: prakṛter guṇa-sammūḍhāḥ sajjante guṇa-karmasu | tān akṛtsna-vido mandān kṛtsna-vin na vicālayet ||
verses.translation: Th' untaught live mixed with them, knowing not Nature's way, of highest aims unwitting, slow and dull. Those make thou not to stumble, having the light.
verses.teaching: Those deluded by the modes of nature become attached to the activities of the modes. The wise should not disturb the minds of the ignorant who have incomplete knowledge, but should engage them gradually.

verses.sanskrit: मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि संन्यस्याध्यात्मचेतसा। निराशीर्निर्ममो भूत्वा युध्यस्व विगतज्वरः॥
verses.transliteration: mayi sarvāṇi karmāṇi sannyasyādhyātma-cetasā | nirāśīr nirmamo bhūtvā yudhyasva vigata-jvaraḥ ||
verses.translation: But all thy dues discharging, for My sake, with meditation centred inwardly, seeking no profit, satisfied, serene, heedless of issue—fight!
verses.teaching: Surrendering all actions to Me with full consciousness of the Self, being free from desire and possessiveness, and cured of mental fever - fight! This is the essence of karma-yoga: dedicated action without attachment.

verses.sanskrit: ये मे मतमिदं नित्यमनुतिष्ठन्ति मानवाः। श्रद्धावन्तोऽनसूयन्तो मुच्यन्ते तेऽपि कर्मभिः॥
verses.transliteration: ye me matam idaṁ nityam anutiṣṭhanti mānavāḥ | śraddhāvanto 'nasūyanto mucyante te 'pi karmabhiḥ ||
verses.translation: They who shall keep my ordinance thus, the wise and willing hearts, have quittance from all issue of their acts.
verses.teaching: Those who regularly follow this teaching of Mine with faith and without envy are freed from the bondage of actions. Simple faith and sincere practice lead to liberation.

verses.sanskrit: ये त्वेतदभ्यसूयन्तो नानुतिष्ठन्ति मे मतम्। सर्वज्ञानविमूढांस्तान्विद्धि नष्टानचेतसः॥
verses.transliteration: ye tv etad abhyasūyanto nānutiṣṭhanti me matam | sarva-jñāna-vimūḍhāṁs tān viddhi naṣṭān acetasaḥ ||
verses.translation: But those who disregard My ordinance, thinking they know, know nought, and fall to loss, confused and foolish.
verses.teaching: But those who find fault with My teaching and do not practice it are deluded in all knowledge, devoid of discrimination, and doomed to ignorance and bondage. Criticism without practice leads nowhere.

verses.sanskrit: सदृशं चेष्टते स्वस्याः प्रकृतेर्ज्ञानवानपि। प्रकृतिं यान्ति भूतानि निग्रहः किं करिष्यति॥
verses.transliteration: sadṛśaṁ ceṣṭate svasyāḥ prakṛter jñānavān api | prakṛtiṁ yānti bhūtāni nigrahaḥ kiṁ kariṣyati ||
verses.translation: 'Sooth, the instructed one doth of his kind, following what fits him most: and lower creatures of their kind; in vain contending 'gainst the law.
verses.teaching: Even the wise act according to their nature; all beings follow their nature. What can mere repression accomplish? We must work with our nature, refining it through practice rather than fighting against it.

verses.sanskrit: इन्द्रियस्येन्द्रियस्यार्थे रागद्वेषौ व्यवस्थितौ। तयोर्न वशमागच्छेत्तौ ह्यस्य परिपन्थिनौ॥
verses.transliteration: indriyasyendriyasyārthe rāga-dveṣau vyavasthitau | tayor na vaśam āgacchet tau hy asya paripanthinau ||
verses.translation: Needs must it be the objects of the sense will stir the sense to like and dislike, yet th' enlightened man yields not to these, knowing them enemies.
verses.teaching: Attraction and aversion for sense objects are natural, but one should not come under their control, for they are obstacles on the path. We must acknowledge these tendencies while not being controlled by them.

verses.sanskrit: श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात्। स्वधर्मे निधनं श्रेयः परधर्मो भयावहः॥
verses.transliteration: śreyān sva-dharmo viguṇaḥ para-dharmāt sv-anuṣṭhitāt | sva-dharme nidhanaṁ śreyaḥ para-dharmo bhayāvahaḥ ||
verses.translation: Finally, this is better, that one do his own task as he may, even though he fail, than take tasks not his own, though they seem good. To die performing duty is no ill; but who seeks other roads shall wander still.
verses.teaching: It is better to perform one's own duty imperfectly than to perform another's duty perfectly. Even death in one's own duty is preferable; another's duty brings danger. Each person has their unique path.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच अथ केन प्रयुक्तोऽयं पापं चरति पूरुषः। अनिच्छन्नपि वार्ष्णेय बलादिव नियोजितः॥
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca atha kena prayukto 'yaṁ pāpaṁ carati pūruṣaḥ | anicchann api vārṣṇeya balād iva niyojitaḥ ||
verses.translation: Yet tell me, Teacher! by what force doth man go to his ill, unwilling; as if one pushed him that evil path?
verses.teaching: Arjuna asks the crucial question: What compels a person to commit sin even against their will, as if forced? This shows the recognition that we often act against our better judgment.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच काम एष क्रोध एष रजोगुणसमुद्भवः। महाशनो महापाप्मा विद्ध्येनमिह वैरिणम्॥
verses.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca kāma eṣa krodha eṣa rajo-guṇa-samudbhavaḥ | mahāśano mahā-pāpmā viddhy enam iha vairiṇam ||
verses.translation: Kama it is! Passion it is! born of the Darknesses, which pusheth him. Mighty of appetite, sinful, and strong is this!—man's enemy!
verses.teaching: The Supreme Lord said: It is lust and anger, born from the mode of passion, which are all-devouring and greatly sinful. Know this to be the enemy. Desire transforms into anger when frustrated.

verses.sanskrit: धूमेनाव्रियते वह्निर्यथादर्शो मलेन च। यथोल्बेनावृतो गर्भस्तथा तेनेदमावृतम्॥
verses.transliteration: dhūmenāvriyate vahnir yathādarśo malena ca | yatholbenāvṛto garbhas tathā tenedam āvṛtam ||
verses.translation: As smoke blots the white fire, as clinging rust mars the bright mirror, as the womb surrounds the babe unborn, so is the world of things foiled, soiled, enclosed in this desire of flesh.
verses.teaching: As fire is covered by smoke, a mirror by dust, and an embryo by the womb, so is knowledge covered by desire. These analogies show different degrees of obscuration - some easier to remove than others.

verses.sanskrit: आवृतं ज्ञानमेतेन ज्ञानिनो नित्यवैरिणा। कामरूपेण कौन्तेय दुष्पूरेणानलेन च॥
verses.transliteration: āvṛtaṁ jñānam etena jñānino nitya-vairiṇā | kāma-rūpeṇa kaunteya duṣpūreṇānalena ca ||
verses.translation: The wise fall, caught in it; the unresting foe it is of wisdom, wearing countless forms, fair but deceitful, subtle as a flame.
verses.teaching: O son of Kunti, knowledge is covered by this eternal enemy in the form of insatiable desire, which is like fire. Desire can never be fully satisfied and always seeks more fuel.

verses.sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणि मनो बुद्धिरस्याधिष्ठानमुच्यते। एतैर्विमोहयत्येष ज्ञानमावृत्य देहिनम्॥
verses.transliteration: indriyāṇi mano buddhir asyādhiṣṭhānam ucyate | etair vimohayaty eṣa jñānam āvṛtya dehinam ||
verses.translation: Sense, mind, and reason—these, O Kunti's Son! are booty for it; in its play with these it maddens man, beguiling, blinding him.
verses.teaching: The senses, mind, and intelligence are said to be the seats of desire. Through these, desire covers knowledge and deludes the embodied soul. Understanding where desire operates helps us combat it.

verses.sanskrit: तस्मात्त्वमिन्द्रियाण्यादौ नियम्य भरतर्षभ। पाप्मानं प्रजहि ह्येनं ज्ञानविज्ञाननाशनम्॥
verses.transliteration: tasmāt tvam indriyāṇy ādau niyamya bharatarṣabha | pāpmānaṁ prajahi hy enaṁ jñāna-vijñāna-nāśanam ||
verses.translation: Therefore, thou noblest child of Bharata! govern thy heart! Constrain th' entangled sense! Resist the false, soft sinfulness which saps knowledge and judgment!
verses.teaching: Therefore, O best of the Bharatas, control your senses from the very beginning and slay this sinful enemy which destroys both knowledge and realization. Self-control is the first step to victory over desire.

verses.sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणि पराण्याहुरिन्द्रियेभ्यः परं मनः। मनसस्तु परा बुद्धिर्यो बुद्धेः परतस्तु सः॥
verses.transliteration: indriyāṇi parāṇy āhur indriyebhyaḥ paraṁ manaḥ | manasas tu parā buddhir yo buddheḥ paratas tu saḥ ||
verses.translation: Yea, the world is strong, but what discerns it stronger, and the mind strongest; and high o'er all the ruling Soul.
verses.teaching: The senses are said to be superior to the body; the mind is superior to the senses; the intelligence is superior to the mind; and the soul is superior to the intelligence. Understanding this hierarchy helps us gain mastery.

verses.sanskrit: एवं बुद्धेः परं बुद्ध्वा संस्तभ्यात्मानमात्मना। जहि शत्रुं महाबाहो कामरूपं दुरासदम्॥
verses.transliteration: evaṁ buddheḥ paraṁ buddhvā saṁstabhyātmānam ātmanā | jahi śatruṁ mahā-bāho kāma-rūpaṁ durāsadam ||
verses.translation: Wherefore, perceiving Him who reigns supreme, put forth full force of Soul in thy own soul! Fight! vanquish foes and doubts, dear Hero! slay what haunts thee in fond shapes, and would betray!
verses.teaching: Thus knowing the soul to be superior to the intelligence, O mighty-armed, stabilize the self by the self and conquer this formidable enemy in the form of desire. Use your higher nature to control your lower nature.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच इमं विवस्वते योगं प्रोक्तवानहमव्ययम्। विवस्वान्मनवे प्राह मनुरिक्ष्वाकवेऽब्रवीत्॥
verses.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca imaṁ vivasvate yogaṁ proktavān aham avyayam | vivasvān manave prāha manur ikṣvākave 'bravīt ||
verses.translation: This deathless Yoga, this deep union, I taught Vivaswata, the Lord of Light; Vivaswata to Manu gave it; he to Ikshwaku; so passed it down the line of all my royal Rishis.
verses.teaching: Krishna reveals that this ancient wisdom was first taught to Vivaswata (the sun-god), then passed through a lineage of enlightened kings. Spiritual knowledge has an ancient, sacred lineage that preserves its purity.

verses.sanskrit: एवं परम्पराप्राप्तमिमं राजर्षयो विदुः। स कालेनेह महता योगो नष्टः परन्तप॥
verses.transliteration: evaṁ paramparā-prāptam imaṁ rājarṣayo viduḥ | sa kāleneha mahatā yogo naṣṭaḥ parantapa ||
verses.translation: Then, with years, the truth grew dim and perished, noble Prince! Now once again to thee it is declared—this ancient lore, this mystery supreme—seeing I find thee votary and friend.
verses.teaching: The royal sages understood this knowledge received through disciplic succession. But over time this yoga was lost. Krishna is now re-establishing it through Arjuna. Truth must be periodically renewed.

verses.sanskrit: स एवायं मया तेऽद्य योगः प्रोक्तः पुरातनः। भक्तोऽसि मे सखा चेति रहस्यं ह्येतदुत्तमम्॥
verses.transliteration: sa evāyaṁ mayā te 'dya yogaḥ proktaḥ purātanaḥ | bhakto 'si me sakhā ceti rahasyaṁ hy etad uttamam ||
verses.translation: Seeing I find thee votary and friend.
verses.teaching: That same ancient yoga has been declared to you by Me today because you are My devotee and friend. This is a supreme secret. Spiritual knowledge is revealed to those who have devotion and friendship with the Divine.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच अपरं भवतो जन्म परं जन्म विवस्वतः। कथमेतद्विजानीयां त्वमादौ प्रोक्तवानिति॥
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca aparaṁ bhavato janma paraṁ janma vivasvataḥ | katham etad vijānīyāṁ tvam ādau proktavān iti ||
verses.translation: Thy birth, dear Lord, was in these later days, and bright Vivaswata's preceded time! How shall I comprehend this thing thou sayest, 'From the beginning it was I who taught?'
verses.teaching: Arjuna's logical question: How could you have taught this to Vivaswata who lived in ancient times when you were born recently? This sets up Krishna's revelation of His divine nature.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच बहूनि मे व्यतीतानि जन्मानि तव चार्जुन। तान्यहं वेद सर्वाणि न त्वं वेत्थ परन्तप॥
verses.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca bahūni me vyatītāni janmāni tava cārjuna | tāny ahaṁ veda sarvāṇi na tvaṁ vettha parantapa ||
verses.translation: Manifold the renewals of my birth have been, Arjuna! and of thy births, too! But mine I know, and thine thou knowest not, O Slayer of thy Foes!
verses.teaching: The Supreme Lord said: Many births of Mine have passed, and many of yours, O Arjuna. I know them all, but you do not. The Divine has complete knowledge of all incarnations while we remain forgetful.

verses.sanskrit: अजोऽपि सन्नव्ययात्मा भूतानामीश्वरोऽपि सन्। प्रकृतिं स्वामधिष्ठाय सम्भवाम्यात्ममायया॥
verses.transliteration: ajo 'pi sann avyayātmā bhūtānām īśvaro 'pi san | prakṛtiṁ svām adhiṣṭhāya sambhavāmy ātma-māyayā ||
verses.translation: Albeit I be unborn, undying, indestructible, the Lord of all things living; not the less—by Maya, by my magic which I stamp on floating Nature-forms, the primal vast—I come, and go, and come.
verses.teaching: Though I am unborn and imperishable, and though I am the Lord of all beings, I appear in My original form by controlling My own material nature through My internal potency. The Divine descends by His own will.

verses.sanskrit: यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत। अभ्युत्थानमधर्मस्य तदात्मानं सृजाम्यहम्॥
verses.transliteration: yadā yadā hi dharmasya glānir bhavati bhārata | abhyutthānam adharmasya tadātmānaṁ sṛjāmy aham ||
verses.translation: When Righteousness declines, O Bharata! when Wickedness is strong, I rise, from age to age, and take visible shape, and move a man with men.
verses.teaching: Whenever there is a decline of righteousness and a rise of unrighteousness, O Bharata, then I manifest Myself. This famous verse explains why divine incarnations occur - to restore dharma when it declines.

verses.sanskrit: परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम्। धर्मसंस्थापनार्थाय सम्भवामि युगे युगे॥
verses.transliteration: paritrāṇāya sādhūnāṁ vināśāya ca duṣkṛtām | dharma-saṁsthāpanārthāya sambhavāmi yuge yuge ||
verses.translation: Succouring the good, thrusting the evil back, and setting Virtue on her seat again.
verses.teaching: For the protection of the good, the destruction of the wicked, and the establishment of righteousness, I appear age after age. The Divine has three purposes: protect devotees, defeat evil, and restore dharma.

verses.sanskrit: जन्म कर्म च मे दिव्यमेवं यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः। त्यक्त्वा देहं पुनर्जन्म नैति मामेति सोऽर्जुन॥
verses.transliteration: janma karma ca me divyam evaṁ yo vetti tattvataḥ | tyaktvā dehaṁ punar janma naiti mām eti so 'rjuna ||
verses.translation: Who knows the truth touching my births on earth and my divine work, when he quits the flesh puts on its load no more, falls no more down to earthly birth: to Me he comes, dear Prince!
verses.teaching: One who knows the transcendental nature of My appearance and activities does not, upon leaving the body, take birth again in this material world, but attains My eternal abode. Understanding God's divine nature leads to liberation.

verses.sanskrit: वीतरागभयक्रोधा मन्मया मामुपाश्रिताः। बहवो ज्ञानतपसा पूता मद्भावमागताः॥
verses.transliteration: vīta-rāga-bhaya-krodhā man-mayā mām upāśritāḥ | bahavo jñāna-tapasā pūtā mad-bhāvam āgatāḥ ||
verses.translation: Many there be who come! from fear set free, from anger, from desire; keeping their hearts fixed upon me—my Faithful—purified by sacred flame of Knowledge. Such as these mix with my being.
verses.teaching: Being freed from attachment, fear, and anger, fully absorbed in Me and taking refuge in Me, many persons in the past became purified by knowledge and penance and attained love for Me.

verses.sanskrit: ये यथा मां प्रपद्यन्ते तांस्तथैव भजाम्यहम्। मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः॥
verses.transliteration: ye yathā māṁ prapadyante tāṁs tathaiva bhajāmy aham | mama vartmānuvartante manuṣyāḥ pārtha sarvaśaḥ ||
verses.translation: Whoso worship me, them I exalt; but all men everywhere shall fall into my path; albeit, those souls which seek reward for works, make sacrifice now, to the lower gods.
verses.teaching: As people surrender to Me, I reward them accordingly. Everyone follows My path in all respects, O Partha. The Divine reciprocates with each person according to their approach and devotion.

verses.sanskrit: काङ्क्षन्तः कर्मणां सिद्धिं यजन्त इह देवताः। क्षिप्रं हि मानुषे लोके सिद्धिर्भवति कर्मजा॥
verses.transliteration: kāṅkṣantaḥ karmaṇāṁ siddhiṁ yajanta iha devatāḥ | kṣipraṁ hi mānuṣe loke siddhir bhavati karma-jā ||
verses.translation: I say to thee here have they their reward. But I am He made the Four Castes, and portioned them a place after their qualities and gifts.
verses.teaching: Those desiring success from their actions worship the demigods, for in this human world success from work comes quickly. Material results come fast through such worship, but they are temporary.

verses.sanskrit: चातुर्वर्ण्यं मया सृष्टं गुणकर्मविभागशः। तस्य कर्तारमपि मां विद्ध्यकर्तारमव्ययम्॥
verses.transliteration: cātur-varṇyaṁ mayā sṛṣṭaṁ guṇa-karma-vibhāgaśaḥ | tasya kartāram api māṁ viddhy akartāram avyayam ||
verses.translation: Yea, I created, the Reposeful; I that live immortally, made all those mortal births: for works soil not my essence, being works wrought uninvolved.
verses.teaching: The four divisions of human society were created by Me according to the modes of nature and work. Though I am the creator, know Me to be the non-doer and eternal. Social order reflects natural qualities.

verses.sanskrit: न मां कर्माणि लिम्पन्ति न मे कर्मफले स्पृहा। इति मां योऽभिजानाति कर्मभिर्न स बध्यते॥
verses.transliteration: na māṁ karmāṇi limpanti na me karma-phale spṛhā | iti māṁ yo 'bhijānāti karmabhir na sa badhyate ||
verses.translation: Who knows me acting thus unchained by action, action binds not him; and, so perceiving, all those saints of old worked, seeking for deliverance.
verses.teaching: Actions do not bind Me, nor do I have any desire for the fruits of action. One who understands this truth about Me is also not bound by actions. Understanding God's transcendence frees us.

verses.sanskrit: एवं ज्ञात्वा कृतं कर्म पूर्वैरपि मुमुक्षुभिः। कुरु कर्मैव तस्मात्त्वं पूर्वैः पूर्वतरं कृतम्॥
verses.transliteration: evaṁ jñātvā kṛtaṁ karma pūrvair api mumukṣubhiḥ | kuru karmaiva tasmāt tvaṁ pūrvaiḥ pūrvataraṁ kṛtam ||
verses.translation: Work thou as, in the days gone by, thy fathers did. Thou sayst, perplexed, It hath been asked before by singers and by sages, 'What is act, and what inaction?'
verses.teaching: Knowing this, the ancient seekers of liberation performed their duties. Therefore, you should also perform your duty, following in the footsteps of the ancients. The wisdom of the ages guides right action.

verses.sanskrit: किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयोऽप्यत्र मोहिताः। तत्ते कर्म प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात्॥
verses.transliteration: kiṁ karma kim akarmeti kavayo 'py atra mohitāḥ | tat te karma pravakṣyāmi yaj jñātvā mokṣyase 'śubhāt ||
verses.translation: I will teach thee this, and, knowing, thou shalt learn which work doth save. Needs must one rightly meditate those three—Doing,—not doing,—and undoing.
verses.teaching: What is action and what is inaction? Even the wise are confused about this. I shall explain action to you, knowing which you will be liberated from inauspiciousness. This is a subtle but crucial distinction.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः। अकर्मणश्च बोद्धव्यं गहना कर्मणो गतिः॥
verses.transliteration: karmaṇo hy api boddhavyaṁ boddhavyaṁ ca vikarmaṇaḥ | akarmaṇaś ca boddhavyaṁ gahanā karmaṇo gatiḥ ||
verses.translation: Here thorny and dark the path is! He who sees how action may be rest, rest action—he is wisest 'mid his kind; he hath the truth! He doeth well, acting or resting.
verses.teaching: One must understand the nature of action, wrong action, and inaction. The truth about action is profound and difficult to understand. This requires deep discrimination and wisdom.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येदकर्मणि च कर्म यः। स बुद्धिमान्मनुष्येषु स युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत्॥
verses.transliteration: karmaṇy akarma yaḥ paśyed akarmaṇi ca karma yaḥ | sa buddhimān manuṣyeṣu sa yuktaḥ kṛtsna-karma-kṛt ||
verses.translation: He who sees how action may be rest, rest action—he is wisest 'mid his kind; he hath the truth! He doeth well, acting or resting.
verses.teaching: One who sees inaction in action, and action in inaction, is intelligent among people and situated in the transcendental position, although engaged in all sorts of activities. True wisdom sees beyond appearances.

verses.sanskrit: यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसङ्कल्पवर्जिताः। ज्ञानाग्निदग्धकर्माणं तमाहुः पण्डितं बुधाः॥
verses.transliteration: yasya sarve samārambhāḥ kāma-saṅkalpa-varjitāḥ | jñānāgni-dagdha-karmāṇaṁ tam āhuḥ paṇḍitaṁ budhāḥ ||
verses.translation: Freed in all his works from prickings of desire, burned clean in act by the white fire of truth, the wise call that man wise; and such an one, renouncing fruit of deeds, always content, always self-satisfying, if he works, doth nothing that shall stain his separate soul.
verses.teaching: One whose every endeavor is devoid of desire and selfish motive, whose actions are consumed by the fire of knowledge—such a person is called wise by the learned. Knowledge burns away the binding effects of action.

verses.sanskrit: त्यक्त्वा कर्मफलासङ्गं नित्यतृप्तो निराश्रयः। कर्मण्यभिप्रवृत्तोऽपि नैव किञ्चित्करोति सः॥
verses.transliteration: tyaktvā karma-phalāsaṅgaṁ nitya-tṛpto nirāśrayaḥ | karmaṇy abhipravṛtto 'pi naiva kiñcit karoti saḥ ||
verses.translation: Which—quit of fear and hope—subduing self—rejecting outward impulse—yielding up to body's need nothing save body, dwells sinless amid all sin, with equal calm taking what may befall, by grief unmoved, unmoved by joy, unenvyingly; the same in good and evil fortunes; nowise bound by bond of deeds.
verses.teaching: Abandoning attachment to the fruits of action, always satisfied, independent, such a person does nothing even while engaged in action. Though active, they perform no binding karma because there is no ego-driven motivation.

verses.sanskrit: निराशीर्यतचित्तात्मा त्यक्तसर्वपरिग्रहः। शारीरं केवलं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम्॥
verses.transliteration: nirāśīr yata-cittātmā tyakta-sarva-parigrahaḥ | śārīraṁ kevalaṁ karma kurvan nāpnoti kilbiṣam ||
verses.translation: Nay, but of such an one, whose crave is gone, whose soul is liberate, whose heart is set on truth—of such an one what work he does is work of sacrifice, which passeth purely into ash and smoke consumed upon the altar!
verses.teaching: Without desire, with mind and self controlled, having renounced all possessions, performing only bodily action, such a person incurs no sin. Minimalist living with inner freedom leads to sinless action.

verses.sanskrit: यदृच्छालाभसन्तुष्टो द्वन्द्वातीतो विमत्सरः। समः सिद्धावसिद्धौ च कृत्वापि न निबध्यते॥
verses.transliteration: yadṛcchā-lābha-santuṣṭo dvandvātīto vimatsaraḥ | samaḥ siddhāv asiddhau ca kṛtvāpi na nibadhyate ||
verses.translation: All's then God! The sacrifice is Brahm, the ghee and grain are Brahm, the fire is Brahm, the flesh it eats is Brahm, and unto Brahm attaineth he who, in such office, meditates on Brahm.
verses.teaching: Content with whatever comes unsought, transcending dualities, free from envy, balanced in success and failure—even while acting, such a person is not bound. True equanimity brings freedom from karma.

verses.sanskrit: गतसङ्गस्य मुक्तस्य ज्ञानावस्थितचेतसः। यज्ञायाचरतः कर्म समग्रं प्रविलीयते॥
verses.transliteration: gata-saṅgasya muktasya jñānāvasthita-cetasaḥ | yajñāyācarataḥ karma samagraṁ pravilīyate ||
verses.translation: Some votaries there be who serve the gods with flesh and altar-smoke; but other some who, lighting subtler fires, make purer rite with will of worship.
verses.teaching: The work of one who is free from attachment, liberated, whose mind is established in knowledge, and who acts only for the sake of sacrifice, dissolves entirely. When action becomes pure offering, it loses all binding power.

verses.sanskrit: ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविर्ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम्। ब्रह्मैव तेन गन्तव्यं ब्रह्मकर्मसमाधिना॥
verses.transliteration: brahmārpaṇaṁ brahma havir brahmāgnau brahmaṇā hutam | brahmaiva tena gantavyaṁ brahma-karma-samādhinā ||
verses.translation: All's then God! The sacrifice is Brahm, the ghee and grain are Brahm, the fire is Brahm, the flesh it eats is Brahm, and unto Brahm attaineth he who, in such office, meditates on Brahm.
verses.teaching: The offering is Brahman, the oblation is Brahman, offered by Brahman into the fire of Brahman. Brahman is to be attained by one who sees Brahman in all action. Everything becomes divine when seen with spiritual vision.

verses.sanskrit: दैवमेवापरे यज्ञं योगिनः पर्युपासते। ब्रह्माग्नावपरे यज्ञं यज्ञेनैवोपजुह्वति॥
verses.transliteration: daivam evāpare yajñaṁ yoginaḥ paryupāsate | brahmāgnāv apare yajñaṁ yajñenaivopajuhvati ||
verses.translation: Some votaries there be who serve the gods with flesh and altar-smoke; but other some who, lighting subtler fires, make purer rite with will of worship.
verses.teaching: Some yogis properly worship the demigods by offering sacrifices to them, while others offer the sacrifice of self-realization in the fire of the Supreme Brahman. There are many valid spiritual practices.

verses.sanskrit: श्रोत्रादीनीन्द्रियाण्यन्ये संयमाग्निषु जुह्वति। शब्दादीन्विषयानन्य इन्द्रियाग्निषु जुह्वति॥
verses.transliteration: śrotrādīnīndriyāṇy anye saṁyamāgniṣu juhvati | śabdādīn viṣayān anya indriyāgniṣu juhvati ||
verses.translation: Of the which be they who, in white flame of continence, consume joys of the sense, delights of eye and ear, forgoing tender speech and sound of song.
verses.teaching: Some offer hearing and other senses into the fires of restraint, while others offer sound and other sense objects into the fires of the senses. Different yogis practice different forms of sense control.

verses.sanskrit: सर्वाणीन्द्रियकर्माणि प्राणकर्माणि चापरे। आत्मसंयमयोगाग्नौ जुह्वति ज्ञानदीपिते॥
verses.transliteration: sarvāṇīndriya-karmāṇi prāṇa-karmāṇi cāpare | ātma-saṁyama-yogāgnau juhvati jñāna-dīpite ||
verses.translation: And they who, kindling fires with torch of Truth, burn on a hidden altar-stone the bliss of youth and love, renouncing happiness.
verses.teaching: Others offer all the functions of the senses and the vital airs into the fire of self-controlled yoga, kindled by knowledge. Various methods of yoga all aim at self-control through dedicated practice.

verses.sanskrit: द्रव्ययज्ञास्तपोयज्ञा योगयज्ञास्तथापरे। स्वाध्यायज्ञानयज्ञाश्च यतयः संशितव्रताः॥
verses.transliteration: dravya-yajñās tapo-yajñā yoga-yajñās tathāpare | svādhyāya-jñāna-yajñāś ca yatayaḥ saṁśita-vratāḥ ||
verses.translation: And they who lay for offering there their wealth, their penance, meditation, piety, their steadfast reading of the scrolls, their lore painfully gained with long austerities.
verses.teaching: Some perform sacrifice with material possessions, some with austerities, some with yoga, while others with strict vows study scriptures and cultivate knowledge as their sacrifice. Many paths lead to the same spiritual goal.

verses.sanskrit: अपाने जुह्वति प्राणं प्राणेऽपानं तथापरे। प्राणापानगती रुद्ध्वा प्राणायामपरायणाः॥
verses.transliteration: apāne juhvati prāṇaṁ prāṇe 'pānaṁ tathāpare | prāṇāpāna-gatī ruddhvā prāṇāyāma-parāyaṇāḥ ||
verses.translation: And they who, making silent sacrifice, draw in their breath to feed the flame of thought, and breathe it forth to waft the heart on high, governing the ventage of each entering air lest one sigh pass which helpeth not the soul.
verses.teaching: Still others offer the outgoing breath into the incoming breath, and the incoming breath into the outgoing breath, restraining both, absorbed in breath control. Pranayama is a powerful form of sacrifice.

verses.sanskrit: अपरे नियताहाराः प्राणान्प्राणेषु जुह्वति। सर्वेऽप्येते यज्ञविदो यज्ञक्षपितकल्मषाः॥
verses.transliteration: apare niyatāhārāḥ prāṇān prāṇeṣu juhvati | sarve 'py ete yajña-vido yajña-kṣapita-kalmaṣāḥ ||
verses.translation: And they who, day by day denying needs, lay life itself upon the altar-flame, burning the body wan. Lo! all these keep the rite of offering, as if they slew victims; and all thereby efface much sin.
verses.teaching: Others, restricting their food intake, offer their life breaths into life breaths. All these knowers of sacrifice have their sins destroyed by sacrifice. Every sincere spiritual practice purifies and elevates consciousness.

verses.sanskrit: यज्ञशिष्टामृतभुजो यान्ति ब्रह्म सनातनम्। नायं लोकोऽस्त्ययज्ञस्य कुतोऽन्यः कुरुसत्तम॥
verses.transliteration: yajña-śiṣṭāmṛta-bhujo yānti brahma sanātanam | nāyaṁ loko 'sty ayajñasya kuto 'nyaḥ kuru-sattama ||
verses.translation: Yea! and who feed on the immortal food left of such sacrifice, to Brahma pass, to The Unending. But for him that makes no sacrifice, he hath nor part nor lot even in the present world. How should he share another, O thou Chief of the Kurus!
verses.teaching: Those who partake of the nectar remaining after sacrifice attain the eternal Brahman. O best of the Kurus, for one who does not perform sacrifice, even this world is not happy—how then the next?

verses.sanskrit: एवं बहुविधा यज्ञा वितता ब्रह्मणो मुखे। कर्मजान्विद्धि तान्सर्वानेवं ज्ञात्वा विमोक्ष्यसे॥
verses.transliteration: evaṁ bahu-vidhā yajñā vitatā brahmaṇo mukhe | karma-jān viddhi tān sarvān evaṁ jñātvā vimokṣyase ||
verses.translation: In sight of Brahma all these offerings are spread and are accepted! Comprehend that all proceed by act; for knowing this, thou shalt be quit of doubt.
verses.teaching: Many types of sacrifice are described in the Vedas. Know them all to be born of action. Knowing thus, you will be liberated. Understanding the diversity of spiritual practices leads to freedom.

verses.sanskrit: श्रेयान्द्रव्यमयाद्यज्ञाज्ज्ञानयज्ञः परन्तप। सर्वं कर्माखिलं पार्थ ज्ञाने परिसमाप्यते॥
verses.transliteration: śreyān dravya-mayād yajñāj jñāna-yajñaḥ parantapa | sarvaṁ karmākhilaṁ pārtha jñāne parisamāpyate ||
verses.translation: The sacrifice which Knowledge pays is better than great gifts offered by wealth, since gifts' worth—O my Prince! lies in the mind which gives, the will that serves: and these are gained by reverence, by strong search, by humble heed of those who see the Truth and teach it.
verses.teaching: O scorcher of enemies, sacrifice performed in knowledge is superior to sacrifice made with material possessions. O Partha, all actions in their entirety culminate in knowledge. Knowledge is the highest offering.

verses.sanskrit: तद्विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नेन सेवया। उपदेक्ष्यन्ति ते ज्ञानं ज्ञानिनस्तत्त्वदर्शिनः॥
verses.transliteration: tad viddhi praṇipātena paripraśnena sevayā | upadekṣyanti te jñānaṁ jñāninas tattva-darśinaḥ ||
verses.translation: Knowing Truth, thy heart no more will ache with error, for the Truth shall show all things subdued to thee, as thou to Me.
verses.teaching: Learn this knowledge through prostration, inquiry, and service. The self-realized souls who have seen the truth will impart knowledge to you. True knowledge requires humility, questioning, and devoted service to a teacher.

verses.sanskrit: यज्ज्ञात्वा न पुनर्मोहमेवं यास्यसि पाण्डव। येन भूतान्यशेषेण द्रक्ष्यस्यात्मन्यथो मयि॥
verses.transliteration: yaj jñātvā na punar moham evaṁ yāsyasi pāṇḍava | yena bhūtāny aśeṣeṇa drakṣyasy ātmany atho mayi ||
verses.translation: Knowing Truth, thy heart no more will ache with error, for the Truth shall show all things subdued to thee, as thou to Me.
verses.teaching: Knowing which, O Pandava, you will never again fall into delusion. By this knowledge you will see all beings in your Self, and also in Me. Self-knowledge reveals the unity of all existence.

verses.sanskrit: अपि चेदसि पापेभ्यः सर्वेभ्यः पापकृत्तमः। सर्वं ज्ञानप्लवेनैव वृजिनं सन्तरिष्यसि॥
verses.transliteration: api ced asi pāpebhyaḥ sarvebhyaḥ pāpa-kṛt-tamaḥ | sarvaṁ jñāna-plavenaiva vṛjinaṁ santariṣyasi ||
verses.translation: Moreover, Son of Pandu! wert thou worst of all wrong-doers, this fair ship of Truth should bear thee safe and dry across the sea of thy transgressions.
verses.teaching: Even if you are the most sinful of all sinners, you will cross over the ocean of sin by the boat of knowledge alone. Knowledge is the supreme purifier that can redeem anyone.

verses.sanskrit: यथैधांसि समिद्धोऽग्निर्भस्मसात्कुरुतेऽर्जुन। ज्ञानाग्निः सर्वकर्माणि भस्मसात्कुरुते तथा॥
verses.transliteration: yathaidhāṁsi samiddho 'gnir bhasma-sāt kurute 'rjuna | jñānāgniḥ sarva-karmāṇi bhasma-sāt kurute tathā ||
verses.translation: As the kindled flame feeds on the fuel till it sinks to ash, so unto ash, Arjuna! unto nought the flame of Knowledge wastes works' dross away!
verses.teaching: As a blazing fire reduces wood to ashes, O Arjuna, so does the fire of knowledge reduce all actions to ashes. Knowledge destroys the karmic consequences of all actions.

verses.sanskrit: न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते। तत्स्वयं योगसंसिद्धः कालेनात्मनि विन्दति॥
verses.transliteration: na hi jñānena sadṛśaṁ pavitram iha vidyate | tat svayaṁ yoga-saṁsiddhaḥ kālenātmani vindati ||
verses.translation: There is no purifier like thereto in all this world, and he who seeketh it shall find it—being grown perfect—in himself.
verses.teaching: In this world there is nothing as purifying as knowledge. One who is perfected in yoga finds this knowledge within the self in due course of time. Knowledge is self-revealing to the prepared soul.

verses.sanskrit: श्रद्धावाँल्लभते ज्ञानं तत्परः संयतेन्द्रियः। ज्ञानं लब्ध्वा परां शान्तिमचिरेणाधिगच्छति॥
verses.transliteration: śraddhāvāḻ labhate jñānaṁ tat-paraḥ saṁyatendriyaḥ | jñānaṁ labdhvā parāṁ śāntim acireṇādhigacchati ||
verses.translation: Believing, he receives it when the soul masters itself, and cleaves to Truth, and comes—possessing knowledge—to the higher peace, the uttermost repose.
verses.teaching: The faithful who are devoted and control their senses obtain knowledge. Having obtained knowledge, one quickly attains supreme peace. Faith, dedication, and sense control are prerequisites for knowledge.

verses.sanskrit: अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति। नायं लोकोऽस्ति न परो न सुखं संशयात्मनः॥
verses.transliteration: ajñaś cāśraddadhānaś ca saṁśayātmā vinaśyati | nāyaṁ loko 'sti na para na sukhaṁ saṁśayātmanaḥ ||
verses.translation: But those untaught, and those without full faith, and those who fear are shent; no peace is here or other where, no hope, nor happiness for whoso doubts.
verses.teaching: But the ignorant, the faithless, and the doubter perishes. For the doubting soul there is neither this world, nor the next, nor happiness. Doubt is a destroyer that must be overcome through knowledge.

verses.sanskrit: योगसंन्यस्तकर्माणं ज्ञानसञ्छिन्नसंशयम्। आत्मवन्तं न कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनञ्जय॥
verses.transliteration: yoga-sannyasta-karmāṇaṁ jñāna-sañchinna-saṁśayam | ātmavantaṁ na karmāṇi nibadhnanti dhanañjaya ||
verses.translation: He that, being self-contained, hath vanquished doubt, disparting self from service, soul from works, enlightened and emancipate, my Prince! works fetter him no more!
verses.teaching: O Dhananjaya, one who has renounced actions through yoga, whose doubts are destroyed by knowledge, and who is situated in the self—actions do not bind such a person. Self-knowledge brings complete freedom.

verses.sanskrit: तस्मादज्ञानसम्भूतं हृत्स्थं ज्ञानासिनात्मनः। छित्त्वैनं संशयं योगमातिष्ठोत्तिष्ठ भारत॥
verses.transliteration: tasmād ajñāna-sambhūtaṁ hṛt-sthaṁ jñānāsinātmanaḥ | chittvainaṁ saṁśayaṁ yogam ātiṣṭhottiṣṭha bhārata ||
verses.translation: Cut then atwain with sword of wisdom, Son of Bharata! this doubt that binds thy heart-beats! cleave the bond born of thy ignorance! Be bold and wise! Give thyself to the field with me! Arise!
verses.teaching: Therefore, with the sword of knowledge cut asunder the doubt in your heart born of ignorance. Take refuge in yoga. Stand up and fight, O Bharata! Knowledge is a weapon that cuts through all doubt and confusion.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच संन्यासं कर्मणां कृष्ण पुनर्योगं च शंससि। यच्छ्रेय एतयोरेकं तन्मे ब्रूहि सुनिश्चितम्॥
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca sannyāsaṁ karmaṇāṁ kṛṣṇa punar yogaṁ ca śaṁsasi | yac chreya etayor ekaṁ tan me brūhi su-niścitam ||
verses.translation: Yet, Krishna! at the one time thou dost laud surcease of works, and, at another time, service through work. Of these twain plainly tell which is the better way?
verses.teaching: Arjuna said: O Krishna, first You recommend renunciation of work, and then again You recommend work in devotion. Now definitely tell me which is better. This shows Arjuna's continued confusion about action versus renunciation.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच संन्यासः कर्मयोगश्च निःश्रेयसकरावुभौ। तयोस्तु कर्मसंन्यासात्कर्मयोगो विशिष्यते॥
verses.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca sannyāsaḥ karma-yogaś ca niḥśreyasa-karāv ubhau | tayos tu karma-sannyāsāt karma-yogo viśiṣyate ||
verses.translation: To cease from works is well, and to do works in holiness is well; and both conduct to bliss supreme; but of these twain the better way is his who working piously refraineth not.
verses.teaching: The Supreme Lord said: Both renunciation of work and work in devotion lead to the supreme goal. But of the two, karma-yoga is superior to renunciation of work. Active devotion is better than mere withdrawal.

verses.sanskrit: ज्ञेयः स नित्यसंन्यासी यो न द्वेष्टि न काङ्क्षति। निर्द्वन्द्वो हि महाबाहो सुखं बन्धात्प्रमुच्यते॥
verses.transliteration: jñeyaḥ sa nitya-sannyāsī yo na dveṣṭi na kāṅkṣati | nirdvandvo hi mahā-bāho sukhaṁ bandhāt pramucyate ||
verses.translation: That is the true Renouncer, firm and fixed, who—seeking nought, rejecting nought—dwells proof against the 'opposites.' O valiant Prince! in doing, such breaks lightly from all deed.
verses.teaching: One who neither hates nor desires should be known as a perpetual renunciant. Free from dualities, O mighty-armed, one is easily liberated from bondage. True renunciation is internal, not merely external.

verses.sanskrit: सांख्ययोगौ पृथग्बालाः प्रवदन्ति न पण्डिताः। एकमप्यास्थितः सम्यगुभयोर्विन्दते फलम्॥
verses.transliteration: sāṅkhya-yogau pṛthag bālāḥ pravadanti na paṇḍitāḥ | ekam apy āsthitaḥ samyag ubhayor vindate phalam ||
verses.translation: 'Tis the new scholar talks as they were two, this Sankhya and this Yoga: wise men know who husbands one plucks golden fruit of both!
verses.teaching: Only the ignorant speak of devotional service as different from analytical study of the material world. Those who are truly learned say that one who applies oneself well to one achieves the results of both.

verses.sanskrit: यत्सांख्यैः प्राप्यते स्थानं तद्योगैरपि गम्यते। एकं सांख्यं च योगं च यः पश्यति स पश्यति॥
verses.transliteration: yat sāṅkhyaiḥ prāpyate sthānaṁ tad yogair api gamyate | ekaṁ sāṅkhyaṁ ca yogaṁ ca yaḥ paśyati sa paśyati ||
verses.translation: The region of high rest which Sankhyans reach Yogins attain. Who sees these twain as one sees with clear eyes!
verses.teaching: The place that is reached by the followers of analytical study is also attained by those engaged in devotional service. One who sees analytical study and devotional service as the same actually sees things as they are.

verses.sanskrit: संन्यासस्तु महाबाहो दुःखमाप्तुमयोगतः। योगयुक्तो मुनिर्ब्रह्म नचिरेणाधिगच्छति॥
verses.transliteration: sannyāsas tu mahā-bāho duḥkham āptum ayogataḥ | yoga-yukto munir brahma na cireṇādhigacchati ||
verses.translation: Yet such abstraction, Chief! is hard to win without much holiness. Whoso is fixed in holiness, self-ruled, pure-hearted, lord of senses and of self, lost in the common life of all which lives—a 'Yogayukt'—he is a Saint who wends straightway to Brahm.
verses.teaching: But renunciation, O mighty-armed, is difficult to attain without yoga. The sage equipped with yoga quickly attains Brahman. Mere renunciation without yoga practice is challenging and incomplete.

verses.sanskrit: योगयुक्तो विशुद्धात्मा विजितात्मा जितेन्द्रियः। सर्वभूतात्मभूतात्मा कुर्वन्नपि न लिप्यते॥
verses.transliteration: yoga-yukto viśuddhātmā vijitātmā jitendriyaḥ | sarva-bhūtātma-bhūtātmā kurvann api na lipyate ||
verses.translation: Such an one is not touched by taint of deeds. 'Nought of myself I do!' thus will he think—who holds the truth of truths—in seeing, hearing, touching, smelling; when he eats, or goes, or breathes; slumbers or talks, holds fast or loosens, opes his eyes or shuts.
verses.teaching: One who is engaged in yoga, whose self is pure, who has conquered the mind and senses, and who realizes the self in all beings—though working, such a person is not tainted. Inner purity protects from karmic bondage.

verses.sanskrit: नैव किञ्चित्करोमीति युक्तो मन्येत तत्त्ववित्। पश्यञ्शृण्वन्स्पृशञ्जिघ्रन्नश्नन्गच्छन्स्वपञ्श्वसन्॥
verses.transliteration: naiva kiñcit karomīti yukto manyeta tattva-vit | paśyañ śṛṇvan spṛśañ jighran naśnan gacchan svapañ śvasan ||
verses.translation: 'Nought of myself I do!' thus will he think—who holds the truth of truths—in seeing, hearing, touching, smelling.
verses.teaching: One who is in divine consciousness and knows the truth thinks, 'I do nothing at all'—even while seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, walking, sleeping, and breathing.

verses.sanskrit: प्रलपन्विसृजन्गृह्णन्नुन्मिषन्निमिषन्नपि। इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेषु वर्तन्त इति धारयन्॥
verses.transliteration: pralapan visṛjan gṛhṇann unmiṣan nimiṣann api | indriyāṇīndriyārtheṣu vartanta iti dhārayan ||
verses.translation: Always assured 'This is the sense-world plays with senses.' He that acts in thought of Brahm, detaching end from act, with act content, the world of sense can no more stain his soul than waters mar th' enamelled lotus-leaf.
verses.teaching: Speaking, releasing, grasping, opening and closing the eyes—one should understand that only the senses are engaging with sense objects. The enlightened person sees the machinery of nature operating while the Self remains uninvolved.

verses.sanskrit: ब्रह्मण्याधाय कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा करोति यः। लिप्यते न स पापेन पद्मपत्रमिवाम्भसा॥
verses.transliteration: brahmaṇy ādhāya karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā karoti yaḥ | lipyate na sa pāpena padma-patram ivāmbhasā ||
verses.translation: He that acts in thought of Brahm, detaching end from act, with act content, the world of sense can no more stain his soul than waters mar th' enamelled lotus-leaf.
verses.teaching: One who performs actions, offering them to Brahman and abandoning attachment, is not tainted by sin—just as a lotus leaf is untouched by water. Dedication to the Divine purifies all action.

verses.sanskrit: कायेन मनसा बुद्ध्या केवलैरिन्द्रियैरपि। योगिनः कर्म कुर्वन्ति सङ्गं त्यक्त्वात्मशुद्धये॥
verses.transliteration: kāyena manasā buddhyā kevalair indriyair api | yoginaḥ karma kurvanti saṅgaṁ tyaktvātma-śuddhaye ||
verses.translation: With life, with heart, with mind,—nay, with the help of all five senses—letting selfhood go—Yogins toil ever towards their souls' release.
verses.teaching: Yogis, abandoning attachment, act with body, mind, intelligence, and senses only for the purpose of self-purification. All actions become means of spiritual purification when done without attachment.

verses.sanskrit: युक्तः कर्मफलं त्यक्त्वा शान्तिमाप्नोति नैष्ठिकीम्। अयुक्तः कामकारेण फले सक्तो निबध्यते॥
verses.transliteration: yuktaḥ karma-phalaṁ tyaktvā śāntim āpnoti naiṣṭhikīm | ayuktaḥ kāma-kāreṇa phale sakto nibadhyate ||
verses.translation: Such votaries, renouncing fruit of deeds, gain endless peace: the unvowed, the passion-bound, seeking a fruit from works, are fastened down.
verses.teaching: The steadily devoted soul attains unadulterated peace by abandoning attachment to the fruits of work; but the unsteady, driven by desire and attached to results, becomes entangled. Peace comes from detachment.

verses.sanskrit: सर्वकर्माणि मनसा संन्यस्यास्ते सुखं वशी। नवद्वारे पुरे देही नैव कुर्वन्न कारयन्॥
verses.transliteration: sarva-karmāṇi manasā sannyasyāste sukhaṁ vaśī | nava-dvāre pure dehī naiva kurvan na kārayan ||
verses.translation: The embodied sage, withdrawn within his soul, at every act sits godlike in 'the town which hath nine gateways,' neither doing aught nor causing any deed.
verses.teaching: Mentally renouncing all actions, the self-controlled embodied being resides happily in the city of nine gates, neither acting nor causing action. The wise person lives in the body but is not of it.

verses.sanskrit: न कर्तृत्वं न कर्माणि लोकस्य सृजति प्रभुः। न कर्मफलसंयोगं स्वभावस्तु प्रवर्तते॥
verses.transliteration: na kartṛtvaṁ na karmāṇi lokasya sṛjati prabhuḥ | na karma-phala-saṁyogaṁ svabhāvas tu pravartate ||
verses.translation: This world's Lord makes neither the work, nor passion for the work, nor lust for fruit of work; the man's own self pushes to these!
verses.teaching: The embodied soul neither creates actions, nor the sense of agency, nor the connection between action and fruit. It is material nature that acts. Understanding this distinction brings freedom from false identification.

verses.sanskrit: नादत्ते कस्यचित्पापं न चैव सुकृतं विभुः। अज्ञानेनावृतं ज्ञानं तेन मुह्यन्ति जन्तवः॥
verses.transliteration: nādatte kasyacit pāpaṁ na caiva sukṛtaṁ vibhuḥ | ajñānenāvṛtaṁ jñānaṁ tena muhyanti jantavaḥ ||
verses.translation: The Master of this World takes on himself the good or evil deeds of no man—dwelling beyond! Mankind errs here by folly, darkening knowledge.
verses.teaching: The all-pervading Spirit does not take on anyone's sinful or pious activities. Knowledge is covered by ignorance; therefore living beings are bewildered. God doesn't create our karma—ignorance does.

verses.sanskrit: ज्ञानेन तु तदज्ञानं येषां नाशितमात्मनः। तेषामादित्यवज्ज्ञानं प्रकाशयति तत्परम्॥
verses.transliteration: jñānena tu tad ajñānaṁ yeṣāṁ nāśitam ātmanaḥ | teṣām āditya-vaj jñānaṁ prakāśayati tat param ||
verses.translation: But, for whom that darkness of the soul is chased by light, splendid and clear shines manifest the Truth as if a Sun of Wisdom sprang to shed its beams of dawn.
verses.teaching: But for those whose ignorance is destroyed by knowledge of the Self, that knowledge reveals the Supreme like the sun illuminating everything. Knowledge is the light that dispels the darkness of ignorance.

verses.sanskrit: तद्बुद्धयस्तदात्मानस्तन्निष्ठास्तत्परायणाः। गच्छन्त्यपुनरावृत्तिं ज्ञाननिर्धूतकल्मषाः॥
verses.transliteration: tad-buddhayas tad-ātmānas tan-niṣṭhās tat-parāyaṇāḥ | gacchanty apunar-āvṛttiṁ jñāna-nirdhūta-kalmaṣāḥ ||
verses.translation: Him meditating still, Him seeking, with Him blended, stayed on Him, the souls illuminated take that road which hath no turning back—their sins flung off by strength of faith.
verses.teaching: Those whose intellect and self are absorbed in the Supreme, who are firmly established in Him as their ultimate goal, attain liberation from rebirth, their sins washed away by knowledge. Total absorption leads to freedom.

verses.sanskrit: विद्याविनयसम्पन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि। शुनि चैव श्वपाके च पण्डिताः समदर्शिनः॥
verses.transliteration: vidyā-vinaya-sampanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini | śuni caiva śva-pāke ca paṇḍitāḥ sama-darśinaḥ ||
verses.translation: Who will may have this Light; who hath it sees. To him who wisely sees, the Brahman with his scrolls and sanctities, the cow, the elephant, the unclean dog, the Outcast gorging dog's meat, are all one.
verses.teaching: The wise see with equal vision a learned and humble brahmin, a cow, an elephant, a dog, and even an outcaste. True knowledge transcends all external distinctions and sees the divine essence in all beings.

verses.sanskrit: इहैव तैर्जितः सर्गो येषां साम्ये स्थितं मनः। निर्दोषं हि समं ब्रह्म तस्माद्ब्रह्मणि ते स्थिताः॥
verses.transliteration: ihaiva tair jitaḥ sargo yeṣāṁ sāmye sthitaṁ manaḥ | nirdoṣaṁ hi samaṁ brahma tasmād brahmaṇi te sthitāḥ ||
verses.translation: The world is overcome—aye! even here!—by such as fix their faith on Unity. The sinless Brahma dwells in Unity, and they in Brahma.
verses.teaching: Those whose minds are established in equanimity have conquered the cycle of birth and death even in this life. Since Brahman is spotless and equal, they are situated in Brahman. Equal vision brings liberation now.

verses.sanskrit: न प्रहृष्येत्प्रियं प्राप्य नोद्विजेत्प्राप्य चाप्रियम्। स्थिरबुद्धिरसम्मूढो ब्रह्मविद्ब्रह्मणि स्थितः॥
verses.transliteration: na prahṛṣyet priyaṁ prāpya nodvijet prāpya cāpriyam | sthira-buddhir asammūḍho brahma-vid brahmaṇi sthitaḥ ||
verses.translation: Be not over-glad attaining joy, and be not over-sad encountering grief, but, stayed on Brahma, still constant let each abide!
verses.teaching: One who is not elated on obtaining what is pleasant, nor disturbed on obtaining the unpleasant, who has steady intelligence, is undeluded, knows Brahman, and is established in Brahman. Equanimity in all circumstances is the sign of wisdom.

verses.sanskrit: बाह्यस्पर्शेष्वसक्तात्मा विन्दत्यात्मनि यत्सुखम्। स ब्रह्मयोगयुक्तात्मा सुखमक्षयमश्नुते॥
verses.transliteration: bāhya-sparśeṣv asaktātmā vindaty ātmani yat sukham | sa brahma-yoga-yuktātmā sukham akṣayam aśnute ||
verses.translation: The sage whose soul holds off from outer contacts, in himself finds bliss; to Brahma joined by piety, his spirit tastes eternal peace.
verses.teaching: One who is not attached to external sense pleasures finds happiness within the Self. Such a person, engaged in meditation on Brahman, attains unlimited happiness. True joy is internal, not external.

verses.sanskrit: ये हि संस्पर्शजा भोगा दुःखयोनय एव ते। आद्यन्तवन्तः कौन्तेय न तेषु रमते बुधः॥
verses.transliteration: ye hi saṁsparśa-jā bhogā duḥkha-yonaya eva te | ādy-antavantaḥ kaunteya na teṣu ramate budhaḥ ||
verses.translation: The joys springing from sense-life are but quickening wombs which breed sure griefs: those joys begin and end! The wise mind takes no pleasure, Kunti's Son! in such as those!
verses.teaching: Pleasures born of sense contact are indeed sources of misery, for they have a beginning and an end, O son of Kunti. The wise person does not rejoice in them. All material pleasures are temporary and ultimately unsatisfying.

verses.sanskrit: शक्नोतीहैव यः सोढुं प्राक्शरीरविमोक्षणात्। कामक्रोधोद्भवं वेगं स युक्तः स सुखी नरः॥
verses.transliteration: śaknotīhaiva yaḥ soḍhuṁ prāk śarīra-vimokṣaṇāt | kāma-krodhodbhavaṁ vegaṁ sa yuktaḥ sa sukhī naraḥ ||
verses.translation: But if a man shall learn, even while he lives and bears his body's chain, to master lust and anger, he is blest! He is the Yukta; he hath happiness, contentment, light, within: his life is merged in Brahma's life; he doth Nirvana touch!
verses.teaching: One who is able to withstand the impulses of desire and anger even before giving up this body—such a person is a yogi and is happy in this world. Self-mastery in this life is the goal, not waiting for death.

verses.sanskrit: योऽन्तःसुखोऽन्तरारामस्तथान्तर्ज्योतिरेव यः। स योगी ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं ब्रह्मभूतोऽधिगच्छति॥
verses.transliteration: yo 'ntaḥ-sukho 'ntar-ārāmas tathāntar-jyotir eva yaḥ | sa yogī brahma-nirvāṇaṁ brahma-bhūto 'dhigacchati ||
verses.translation: He is the Yukta; he hath happiness, contentment, light, within: his life is merged in Brahma's life; he doth Nirvana touch!
verses.teaching: One who is happy within, who rejoices within, who is illumined within—such a yogi becomes Brahman and attains liberation in Brahman. The enlightened person finds everything within, needing nothing external.

verses.sanskrit: लभन्ते ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृषयः क्षीणकल्मषाः। छिन्नद्वैधा यतात्मानः सर्वभूतहिते रताः॥
verses.transliteration: labhante brahma-nirvāṇam ṛṣayaḥ kṣīṇa-kalmaṣāḥ | chinna-dvaidhā yatātmānaḥ sarva-bhūta-hite ratāḥ ||
verses.translation: Thus go the Rishis unto rest, who dwell with sins effaced, with doubts at end, with hearts governed and calm. Glad in all good they live, nigh to the peace of God.
verses.teaching: Seers whose sins have been destroyed, whose doubts are cut asunder, whose minds are disciplined, and who are engaged in the welfare of all beings, attain liberation in Brahman. Service to all beings is the path to God.

verses.sanskrit: कामक्रोधवियुक्तानां यतीनां यतचेतसाम्। अभितो ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं वर्तते विदितात्मनाम्॥
verses.transliteration: kāma-krodha-viyuktānāṁ yatīnāṁ yata-cetasām | abhito brahma-nirvāṇaṁ vartate viditātmanām ||
verses.translation: And all those live who pass their days exempt from greed and wrath, subduing self and senses, knowing the Soul!
verses.teaching: For those self-controlled ascetics who are free from desire and anger, who have controlled their minds and realized the Self, liberation in Brahman exists both here and hereafter. Freedom is available now for the prepared soul.

verses.sanskrit: स्पर्शान्कृत्वा बहिर्बाह्यांश्चक्षुश्चैवान्तरे भ्रुवोः। प्राणापानौ समौ कृत्वा नासाभ्यन्तरचारिणौ॥
verses.transliteration: sparśān kṛtvā bahir bāhyāṁś cakṣuś caivāntare bhruvoḥ | prāṇāpānau samau kṛtvā nāsābhyantara-cāriṇau ||
verses.translation: The Saint who shuts outside his placid soul all touch of sense, letting no contact through; whose quiet eyes gaze straight from fixed brows, whose outward breath and inward breath are drawn equal and slow through nostrils still and close.
verses.teaching: Shutting out external sense objects, fixing the gaze between the eyebrows, equalizing the incoming and outgoing breaths moving within the nostrils—this begins the practice of meditation.

verses.sanskrit: यतेन्द्रियमनोबुद्धिर्मुनिर्मोक्षपरायणः। विगतेच्छाभयक्रोधो यः सदा मुक्त एव सः॥
verses.transliteration: yatendriya-mano-buddhir munir mokṣa-parāyaṇaḥ | vigatecchā-bhaya-krodho yaḥ sadā mukta eva saḥ ||
verses.translation: That one—with organs, heart, and mind constrained, bent on deliverance, having put away passion, and fear, and rage;—hath, even now, obtained deliverance, ever and ever freed.
verses.teaching: The sage devoted to liberation, who has controlled the senses, mind and intelligence, who is free from desire, fear and anger—such a person is forever liberated. Liberation is a state of being, not a future event.

verses.sanskrit: भोक्तारं यज्ञतपसां सर्वलोकमहेश्वरम्। सुहृदं सर्वभूतानां ज्ञात्वा मां शान्तिमृच्छति॥
verses.transliteration: bhoktāraṁ yajña-tapasāṁ sarva-loka-maheśvaram | suhṛdaṁ sarva-bhūtānāṁ jñātvā māṁ śāntim ṛcchati ||
verses.translation: A person in full consciousness of Me, knowing Me to be the ultimate beneficiary of all sacrifices and austerities, the Supreme Lord of all planets and demigods, and the benefactor and well-wisher of all living entities, attains peace from the pangs of material miseries.
verses.teaching: Peace comes from understanding God as the ultimate beneficiary of all actions and the true friend of all beings. This realization removes the ego and brings inner tranquility.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच अनाश्रितः कर्मफलं कार्यं कर्म करोति यः। स संन्यासी च योगी च न निरग्निर्न चाक्रियः॥
verses.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca anāśritaḥ karma-phalaṁ kāryaṁ karma karoti yaḥ | sa sannyāsī ca yogī ca na niragnir na cākriyaḥ ||
verses.translation: Therefore, who doeth work rightful to do, not seeking gain from work, that man, O Prince! is Sanyasi and Yogi—both in one! And he is neither who lights not the flame of sacrifice, nor setteth hand to task.
verses.teaching: One who performs prescribed duties without attachment to results is both a renunciant and a yogi. True renunciation is not about avoiding work, but about working without selfish desire.

verses.sanskrit: यं संन्यासमिति प्राहुर्योगं तं विद्धि पाण्डव। न ह्यसंन्यस्तसङ्कल्पो योगी भवति कश्चन॥
verses.transliteration: yaṁ sannyāsam iti prāhur yogaṁ taṁ viddhi pāṇḍava | na hy asannyasta-saṅkalpo yogī bhavati kaścana ||
verses.translation: Regard as true Renouncer him that makes worship by work, for who renounceth not works not as Yogin. So is that well said: 'By works the votary doth rise to faith, and saintship is the ceasing from all works.'
verses.teaching: What is called renunciation is the same as yoga, O Pandava. No one becomes a yogi without renouncing selfish desires. The two paths are one.

verses.sanskrit: आरुरुक्षोर्मुनेर्योगं कर्म कारणमुच्यते। योगारूढस्य तस्यैव शमः कारणमुच्यते॥
verses.transliteration: ārurukṣor muner yogaṁ karma kāraṇam ucyate | yogārūḍhasya tasyaiva śamaḥ kāraṇam ucyate ||
verses.translation: Because the perfect Yogin acts—but acts unmoved by passions and unbound by deeds, setting result aside. Let each man raise the Self by Soul, not trample down his Self, since Soul that is Self's friend may grow Self's foe.
verses.teaching: For one who is a beginner in yoga, work is said to be the means. For one who has attained yoga, tranquility is said to be the means. Different stages require different practices.

verses.sanskrit: यदा हि नेन्द्रियार्थेषु न कर्मस्वनुषज्जते। सर्वसङ्कल्पसंन्यासी योगारूढस्तदोच्यते॥
verses.transliteration: yadā hi nendriyārtheṣu na karmasv anuṣajjate | sarva-saṅkalpa-sannyāsī yogārūḍhas tadocyate ||
verses.translation: Soul is Self's friend when Self doth rule o'er Self, but Self turns enemy if Soul's own self hates Self as not itself.
verses.teaching: When one is not attached to sense objects or to actions, having renounced all selfish desires, then one is said to have attained yoga. Detachment marks spiritual maturity.

verses.sanskrit: उद्धरेदात्मनात्मानं नात्मानमवसादयेत्। आत्मैव ह्यात्मनो बन्धुरात्मैव रिपुरात्मनः॥
verses.transliteration: uddhared ātmanātmānaṁ nātmānam avasādayet | ātmaiva hy ātmano bandhur ātmaiva ripur ātmanaḥ ||
verses.translation: Let each man raise the Self by Soul, not trample down his Self, since Soul that is Self's friend may grow Self's foe. Soul is Self's friend when Self doth rule o'er Self, but Self turns enemy if Soul's own self hates Self as not itself.
verses.teaching: One should uplift oneself by one's own mind, not degrade oneself. The mind is the friend of the conditioned soul, and the mind is also the enemy. We must use our higher nature to control our lower nature.

verses.sanskrit: बन्धुरात्मात्मनस्तस्य येनात्मैवात्मना जितः। अनात्मनस्तु शत्रुत्वे वर्तेतात्मैव शत्रुवत्॥
verses.transliteration: bandhur ātmātmanas tasya yenātmaivātmanā jitaḥ | anātmanas tu śatrutve vartetātmaiva śatru-vat ||
verses.translation: Soul is Self's friend when Self doth rule o'er Self, but Self turns enemy if Soul's own self hates Self as not itself.
verses.teaching: For one who has conquered the mind, it is the best of friends. But for one who has failed to do so, the mind remains the greatest enemy. Self-mastery is the foundation of spiritual life.

verses.sanskrit: जितात्मनः प्रशान्तस्य परमात्मा समाहितः। शीतोष्णसुखदुःखेषु तथा मानापमानयोः॥
verses.transliteration: jitātmanaḥ praśāntasya paramātmā samāhitaḥ | śītoṣṇa-sukha-duḥkheṣu tathā mānāpamānayoḥ ||
verses.translation: The sovereign soul of him who lives self-governed and at peace is centred in itself, taking alike pleasure and pain; heat, cold; glory and shame.
verses.teaching: For one who has conquered the mind and attained tranquility, the Supreme Self is already reached. Such a person is balanced in cold and heat, pleasure and pain, honor and dishonor.

verses.sanskrit: ज्ञानविज्ञानतृप्तात्मा कूटस्थो विजितेन्द्रियः। युक्त इत्युच्यते योगी समलोष्टाश्मकाञ्चनः॥
verses.transliteration: jñāna-vijñāna-tṛptātmā kūṭa-stho vijitendriyaḥ | yukta ity ucyate yogī sama-loṣṭāśma-kāñcanaḥ ||
verses.translation: He is the Yogi, he is Yukta, glad with joy of light and truth; dwelling apart upon a peak, with senses subjugate whereto the clod, the rock, the glistering gold show all as one.
verses.teaching: A person is considered established in self-realization when satisfied by knowledge and realization, unchanging, with senses controlled, viewing equally a clod of earth, a stone, and gold.

verses.sanskrit: सुहृन्मित्रार्युदासीनमध्यस्थद्वेष्यबन्धुषु। साधुष्वपि च पापेषु समबुद्धिर्विशिष्यते॥
verses.transliteration: suhṛn-mitrāry-udāsīna-madhyastha-dveṣya-bandhuṣu | sādhuṣv api ca pāpeṣu sama-buddhir viśiṣyate ||
verses.translation: By this sign is he known being of equal grace to comrades, friends, chance-comers, strangers, lovers, enemies, aliens and kinsmen; loving all alike, evil or good.
verses.teaching: One who is impartial toward well-wishers, friends, enemies, neutral parties, mediators, the hateful, relatives, saints, and sinners—such a person excels. Equal vision toward all is the mark of the truly enlightened.

verses.sanskrit: योगी युञ्जीत सततमात्मानं रहसि स्थितः। एकाकी यतचित्तात्मा निराशीरपरिग्रहः॥
verses.transliteration: yogī yuñjīta satatam ātmānaṁ rahasi sthitaḥ | ekākī yata-cittātmā nirāśīr aparigrahaḥ ||
verses.translation: Sequestered should he sit, steadfastly meditating, solitary, his thoughts controlled, his passions laid away, quit of belongings.
verses.teaching: The yogi should constantly engage the mind in meditation while living in seclusion, alone, with mind and body controlled, free from desires and possessiveness. Regular practice in solitude develops inner strength.

verses.sanskrit: शुचौ देशे प्रतिष्ठाप्य स्थिरमासनमात्मनः। नात्युच्छ्रितं नातिनीचं चैलाजिनकुशोत्तरम्॥
verses.transliteration: śucau deśe pratiṣṭhāpya sthiram āsanam ātmanaḥ | nāty-ucchritaṁ nāti-nīcaṁ cailājina-kuśottaram ||
verses.translation: In a fair, still spot having his fixed abode,—not too much raised, nor yet too low,—let him abide, his goods a cloth, a deerskin, and the Kusa-grass.
verses.teaching: In a clean, level place, one should establish a firm seat for oneself—neither too high nor too low—covered with sacred grass, a deerskin, and cloth, one over the other. The external environment supports internal practice.

verses.sanskrit: तत्रैकाग्रं मनः कृत्वा यतचित्तेन्द्रियक्रियः। उपविश्यासने युञ्ज्याद्योगमात्मविशुद्धये॥
verses.transliteration: tatraikāgraṁ manaḥ kṛtvā yata-cittendriya-kriyaḥ | upaviśyāsane yuñjyād yogam ātma-viśuddhaye ||
verses.translation: There, setting hard his mind upon The One, restraining heart and senses, silent, calm, let him accomplish Yoga, and achieve pureness of soul.
verses.teaching: Sitting on that seat, making the mind one-pointed and controlling thought and sense activity, one should practice yoga for self-purification. Single-pointed focus is essential for meditation.

verses.sanskrit: समं कायशिरोग्रीवं धारयन्नचलं स्थिरः। सम्प्रेक्ष्य नासिकाग्रं स्वं दिशश्चानवलोकयन्॥
verses.transliteration: samaṁ kāya-śiro-grīvaṁ dhārayann acalaṁ sthiraḥ | samprekṣya nāsikāgraṁ svaṁ diśaś cānavalokayan ||
verses.translation: Holding immovable body and neck and head, his gaze absorbed upon his nose-end, rapt from all around, tranquil in spirit, free of fear, intent upon his Brahmacharya vow, devout, musing on Me, lost in the thought of Me.
verses.teaching: One should hold the body, head, and neck erect and still, gazing at the tip of the nose without looking around. Proper posture supports concentration and meditation.

verses.sanskrit: प्रशान्तात्मा विगतभीर्ब्रह्मचारिव्रते स्थितः। मनः संयम्य मच्चित्तो युक्त आसीत मत्परः॥
verses.transliteration: praśāntātmā vigata-bhīr brahmacāri-vrate sthitaḥ | manaḥ saṁyamya mac-citto yukta āsīta mat-paraḥ ||
verses.translation: Tranquil in spirit, free of fear, intent upon his Brahmacharya vow, devout, musing on Me, lost in the thought of Me.
verses.teaching: With a serene mind, fearless, established in the vow of celibacy, controlling the mind, and thinking of Me, one should sit in meditation, absorbed in Me. Devotional focus transforms meditation.

verses.sanskrit: युञ्जन्नेवं सदात्मानं योगी नियतमानसः। शान्तिं निर्वाणपरमां मत्संस्थामधिगच्छति॥
verses.transliteration: yuñjann evaṁ sadātmānaṁ yogī niyata-mānasaḥ | śāntiṁ nirvāṇa-paramāṁ mat-saṁsthām adhigacchati ||
verses.translation: That Yojin, so devoted, so controlled, comes to the peace beyond,—My peace, the peace of high Nirvana!
verses.teaching: Thus always keeping the mind absorbed in Me, the yogi of controlled mind attains the peace of supreme liberation, which culminates in Me. Constant practice leads to the ultimate goal.

verses.sanskrit: नात्यश्नतस्तु योगोऽस्ति न चैकान्तमनश्नतः। न चातिस्वप्नशीलस्य जाग्रतो नैव चार्जुन॥
verses.transliteration: nāty-aśnatas tu yogo 'sti na caikāntam anaśnataḥ | na cāti-svapna-śīlasya jāgrato naiva cārjuna ||
verses.translation: But for earthly needs religion is not his who too much fasts or too much feasts, nor his who sleeps away an idle mind; nor his who wears to waste his strength in vigils.
verses.teaching: Yoga is not for one who eats too much or too little, sleeps too much or too little. Extremes in either direction obstruct spiritual progress. Balance in daily life supports spiritual practice.

verses.sanskrit: युक्ताहारविहारस्य युक्तचेष्टस्य कर्मसु। युक्तस्वप्नावबोधस्य योगो भवति दुःखहा॥
verses.transliteration: yuktāhāra-vihārasya yukta-ceṣṭasya karmasu | yukta-svapnāvabodhasya yogo bhavati duḥkha-hā ||
verses.translation: Nay, Arjuna! call that the true piety which most removes earth-aches and ills, where one is moderate in eating and in resting, and in sport; measured in wish and act; sleeping betimes, waking betimes for duty.
verses.teaching: One who is temperate in eating and recreation, balanced in work, and regulated in sleep and wakefulness—such yoga destroys all sorrow. Moderation in all things creates the foundation for peace.

verses.sanskrit: यदा विनियतं चित्तमात्मन्येवावतिष्ठते। निःस्पृहः सर्वकामेभ्यो युक्त इत्युच्यते तदा॥
verses.transliteration: yadā viniyataṁ cittam ātmany evāvatiṣṭhate | niḥspṛhaḥ sarva-kāmebhyo yukta ity ucyate tadā ||
verses.translation: When the man, so living, centres on his soul the thought straitly restrained—untouched internally by stress of sense—then is he Yukta.
verses.teaching: When the perfectly disciplined mind becomes established in the Self alone, free from longing for all desires, then one is said to be in yoga. True yoga is union with the inner Self.

verses.sanskrit: यथा दीपो निवातस्थो नेङ्गते सोपमा स्मृता। योगिनो यतचित्तस्य युञ्जतो योगमात्मनः॥
verses.transliteration: yathā dīpo nivāta-stho neṅgate sopamā smṛtā | yogino yata-cittasya yuñjato yogam ātmanaḥ ||
verses.translation: See! steadfast a lamp burns sheltered from the wind; such is the likeness of the Yogi's mind shut from sense-storms and burning bright to Heaven.
verses.teaching: As a lamp in a windless place does not flicker, so the disciplined mind of a yogi remains steady in meditation on the Self. Stability of mind is the hallmark of true meditation.

verses.sanskrit: यत्रोपरमते चित्तं निरुद्धं योगसेवया। यत्र चैवात्मनात्मानं पश्यन्नात्मनि तुष्यति॥
verses.transliteration: yatroparamate cittaṁ niruddhaṁ yoga-sevayā | yatra caivātmanātmānaṁ paśyann ātmani tuṣyati ||
verses.translation: When mind broods placid, soothed with holy wont; when Self contemplates self, and in itself hath comfort.
verses.teaching: In that state where the mind, restrained by the practice of yoga, becomes still, and where one perceives the Self by the Self and rejoices in the Self—this is the beginning of transcendence.

verses.sanskrit: सुखमात्यन्तिकं यत्तद्बुद्धिग्राह्यमतीन्द्रियम्। वेत्ति यत्र न चैवायं स्थितश्चलति तत्त्वतः॥
verses.transliteration: sukham ātyantikaṁ yat tad buddhi-grāhyam atīndriyam | vetti yatra na caivāyaṁ sthitaś calati tattvataḥ ||
verses.translation: When it knows the nameless joy beyond all scope of sense, revealed to soul—only to soul! and, knowing, wavers not, true to the farther Truth.
verses.teaching: In which one experiences unlimited happiness that can be grasped only by the purified intellect beyond the senses, and established thus, one never departs from the truth. This is supreme bliss.

verses.sanskrit: यं लब्ध्वा चापरं लाभं मन्यते नाधिकं ततः। यस्मिन्स्थितो न दुःखेन गुरुणापि विचाल्यते॥
verses.transliteration: yaṁ labdhvā cāparaṁ lābhaṁ manyate nādhikaṁ tataḥ | yasmin sthito na duḥkhena guruṇāpi vicālyate ||
verses.translation: When, holding this, it deems no other treasure comparable, but, harboured there, cannot be stirred or shook by any gravest grief.
verses.teaching: Having gained this, one thinks there is no greater gain. Established in this state, one is not moved even by the heaviest sorrow. This is the touchstone of spiritual realization.

verses.sanskrit: तं विद्याद्दुःखसंयोगवियोगं योगसंज्ञितम्। स निश्चयेन योक्तव्यो योगोऽनिर्विण्णचेतसा॥
verses.transliteration: taṁ vidyād duḥkha-saṁyoga-viyogaṁ yoga-saṁjñitam | sa niścayena yoktavyo yogo 'nirviṇṇa-cetasā ||
verses.translation: Call that state 'peace,' that happy severance Yoga; call that man the perfect Yogin!
verses.teaching: Let it be known that the severance of union with pain is called yoga. This yoga should be practiced with determination and an undiscouraged mind. Persistence is essential.

verses.sanskrit: सङ्कल्पप्रभवान्कामांस्त्यक्त्वा सर्वानशेषतः। मनसैवेन्द्रियग्रामं विनियम्य समन्ततः॥
verses.transliteration: saṅkalpa-prabhavān kāmāṁs tyaktvā sarvān aśeṣataḥ | manasaivendriya-grāmaṁ viniyamya samantataḥ ||
verses.translation: Steadfastly the will must toil thereto, till efforts end in ease, and thought has passed from thinking.
verses.teaching: Abandoning without exception all desires born of selfish intent, completely restraining the multitude of senses by the mind from all sides—this is the practice of detachment.

verses.sanskrit: शनैः शनैरुपरमेद्बुद्ध्या धृतिगृहीतया। आत्मसंस्थं मनः कृत्वा न किञ्चिदपि चिन्तयेत्॥
verses.transliteration: śanaiḥ śanair uparamed buddhyā dhṛti-gṛhītayā | ātma-saṁsthaṁ manaḥ kṛtvā na kiñcid api cintayet ||
verses.translation: Shaking off all longings bred by dreams of fame and gain, shutting the doorways of the senses close with watchful ward; so, step by step, it comes to gift of peace assured and heart assuaged, when the mind dwells self-wrapped, and the soul broods cumberless.
verses.teaching: Gradually, step by step, one should become situated in trance by means of intelligence sustained by full conviction. Fixing the mind on the Self, one should think of nothing else. Progress is gradual but sure.

verses.sanskrit: यतो यतो निश्चरति मनश्चञ्चलमस्थिरम्। ततस्ततो नियम्यैतदात्मन्येव वशं नयेत्॥
verses.transliteration: yato yato niścarati manaś cañcalam asthiram | tatas tato niyamyaitad ātmany eva vaśaṁ nayet ||
verses.translation: But, as often as the heart breaks—wild and wavering—from control, so oft let him re-curb it, let him rein it back to the soul's governance.
verses.teaching: Whenever and wherever the restless and unsteady mind wanders, one should bring it back and continually focus it on the Self. The mind will wander—this is natural—but must be gently brought back.

verses.sanskrit: प्रशान्तमनसं ह्येनं योगिनं सुखमुत्तमम्। उपैति शान्तरजसं ब्रह्मभूतमकल्मषम्॥
verses.transliteration: praśānta-manasaṁ hy enaṁ yoginaṁ sukham uttamam | upaiti śānta-rajasaṁ brahma-bhūtam akalmaṣam ||
verses.translation: For perfect bliss grows only in the bosom tranquillised, the spirit passionless, purged from offence, vowed to the Infinite.
verses.teaching: Supreme happiness comes to the yogi whose mind is peaceful, whose passions are calmed, who is free from sin, and who has become one with Brahman. Peace is the precondition for bliss.

verses.sanskrit: युञ्जन्नेवं सदात्मानं योगी विगतकल्मषः। सुखेन ब्रह्मसंस्पर्शमत्यन्तं सुखमश्नुते॥
verses.transliteration: yuñjann evaṁ sadātmānaṁ yogī vigata-kalmaṣaḥ | sukhena brahma-saṁsparśam atyantaṁ sukham aśnute ||
